Unlike some other digital currencies{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}}, Bitcoin avoids central authorities and issuers. Bitcoin uses a [[distributed database]] spread across nodes of a [[peer-to-peer]] network to journal transactions, and uses [[digital signature]]s and [[proof-of-work system|proof-of-work]] to provide basic security functions, such as ensuring that bitcoins can be spent only once per owner and only by the person who owns them.
Bitcoins, often abbreviated as BTC, can be saved on a personal computer in the form of a ''wallet file'' or kept with a third party ''wallet service'', and in either case bitcoins can be sent over the Internet to anyone with a ''Bitcoin address''. The peer-to-peer topology and lack of central administration are features that make it infeasible for any authority (governmental or otherwise) to manipulate the quantity of bitcoins in circulation, thereby mitigating [[inflation]].<ref name="whitepaper">{{cite book|last=Nakamoto|first=Satoshi|title=Bitcoin: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Cash System|url=http://www.bitcoin.org/bitcoin.pdf|accessdate=14 December 2010|date=24 May 2009}}</ref>
